claim.text: Dense retrieval can outperform and potentially replace the traditional sparse retrieval component in open-domain question answering.
claim.exact_quote: In this work, we demonstrated that dense retrieval can outperform and potentially replace the traditional sparse retrieval component in open-domain question answering.

evidence.evidence_text: The dense passage retriever (DPR) outperforms BM25 by a large margin (65.2% vs. 42.9% in Top-5 accuracy), and results in a substantial improvement on the end-to-end QA accuracy compared to ORQA (41.5% vs. 33.3%) in the open Natural Questions setting.
evidence.limitations: The results are specific to the datasets used and may not generalize to other datasets.
evidence.exact_quote: DPR performs consistently better than BM25 on all datasets. The gap is especially large when k is small (e.g., 78.4% vs. 59.1% for top-20 accuracy on Natural Questions).

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by empirical results showing that DPR outperforms BM25 across multiple datasets.
evaluation.key_limitations: The results are specific to the datasets used and may not generalize to other datasets.

claim.text: A simple dual-encoder approach can be made to work surprisingly well.
claim.exact_quote: Our Dense Passage Retriever (DPR) uses a dense encoder EP (·) which maps any text passage to a d-dimensional real-valued vectors and builds an index for all the M passages that we will use for retrieval.

evidence.evidence_text: The dense passage retriever (DPR) uses a dense encoder EP (·) which maps any text passage to a d-dimensional real-valued vectors and builds an index for all the M passages that we will use for retrieval.
evidence.limitations: The methodology is specific to the datasets and may not generalize to other datasets.
evidence.exact_quote: Our dense passage retriever (DPR) uses a dense encoder EP (·) which maps any text passage to a d-dimensional real-valued vectors and builds an index for all the M passages that we will use for retrieval.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the methodology described in the paper.
evaluation.key_limitations: The methodology is specific to the datasets and may not generalize to other datasets.

claim.text: The embedding is optimized for maximizing inner products of the question and relevant passage vectors.
claim.exact_quote: The embedding is optimized for maximizing inner products of the question and relevant passage vectors, with an objective comparing all pairs of questions and passages in a batch.

evidence.evidence_text: The embedding is optimized for maximizing inner products of the question and relevant passage vectors, with an objective comparing all pairs of questions and passages in a batch.
evidence.limitations: The methodology is specific to the datasets and may not generalize to other datasets.
evidence.exact_quote: The embedding is optimized for maximizing inner products of the question and relevant passage vectors, with an objective comparing all pairs of questions and passages in a batch.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the methodology described in the paper.
evaluation.key_limitations: The methodology is specific to the datasets and may not generalize to other datasets.

claim.text: DPR performs better than BM25 in general, passages retrieved by these two methods differ qualitatively.
claim.exact_quote: Although DPR performs better than BM25 in general, passages retrieved by these two methods differ qualitatively.

evidence.evidence_text: Although DPR performs better than BM25 in general, passages retrieved by these two methods differ qualitatively.
evidence.limitations: The qualitative differences are specific to the datasets and may not generalize to other datasets.
evidence.exact_quote: Although DPR performs better than BM25 in general, passages retrieved by these two methods differ qualitatively.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the qualitative analysis described in the paper.
evaluation.key_limitations: The qualitative differences are specific to the datasets and may not generalize to other datasets.

claim.text: DPR can be made incredibly efficient, processing 995.0 questions per second, returning top 100 passages per question.
claim.exact_quote: With the help of FAISS in-memory index for real-valued vectors, DPR can be made incredibly efficient, processing 995.0 questions per second, returning top 100 passages per question.

evidence.evidence_text: With the help of FAISS in-memory index for real-valued vectors, DPR can be made incredibly efficient, processing 995.0 questions per second, returning top 100 passages per question.
evidence.limitations: The efficiency is specific to the hardware and may not generalize to other hardware configurations.
evidence.exact_quote: With the help of FAISS in-memory index for real-valued vectors, DPR can be made incredibly efficient, processing 995.0 questions per second, returning top 100 passages per question.

evaluation.justification: The claim is supported by the performance metrics described in the paper.
evaluation.key_limitations: The efficiency is specific to the hardware and may not generalize to other hardware configurations.
